analyzeResult.content:
Preventive Medicine 28, 138-148 (1999) Article ID pmed. 1998.0404, available online at http://www.idealibrary.com on LIE
Psychosocial, School, and Parent Factors Associated with Recent Smoking among Early-Adolescent Boys and Girls1
Bruce Simons-Morton, Ed.D., M.P.H.,*2 Aria Davis Crump, Sc.D.,t Denise L. Haynie, Ph.D., M.P.H.,* Keith E. Saylor, Ph.D.,+ Patricia Eitel, Ph.D.," and Kai Yu, Ph.D .*
*Division of Epidemiology, Statistics, and Prevention Research, National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892; tDepartment of Health Education, University of Maryland at College Park, College Park, Maryland 20742; and $Behavior and Health Research, Inc., Rockville, Maryland
Background. Experimentation with smoking often begins during adolescence, but an adequate under- standing of the factors associated with early initiation remains elusive.
Methods. Sixth- to eighth-grade students (n = 4,263, 67.1% white, 23.5% black, 7.2% other) from seven middle schools were surveyed.
Results. The overall prevalence of recent smoking (past 30 days) of 10.4% was similar for boys and girls and by race, but increased from 3.7% in sixth to 17.8% in eighth grade. In multiple logistic regression analyses positive outcome expectations, high perceived preva- lence, deviance acceptance, and trouble at school were independently associated with smoking for both boys and girls. Among boys, problem-behaving friends, peer pressure, authoritative parenting, and mother's educa- tion and among girls, self-control problems, knowl- edgeable parents, and grade were independently asso- ciated with smoking.
Conclusions. This is one of the few studies to report an independent association between smoking and out- come expectations, the first study to report an indepen- dent effect for peer influences among boys only, and one of several to find a negative association between smoking and positive parenting behavior. These find- ings suggest that the effectiveness of preventive inter- ventions might be improved by targeting parent, school, and student outcomes, including outcome ex- pectations, deviance acceptance, and social norms for both boys and girls, peer influences among boys, and self-control among girls. 01119 American Health Foundation and Academic Press
This research was supported by NIH Contract NO1-HD-4-3207. To whom reprint requests should be addressed at the Prevention Research Branch, DESPR, NICHD, Bldg 6100, Room 7B05, 9000 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20892-7510. Fax: (301) 402-2084. E-mail: MORTONB@exchange.nih.gov.
Key Words: adolescent behavior; smoking; cigarettes; psychosocial aspects.
INTRODUCTION
Smoking is one of the most important, preventable causes of disease [1-5]. Experimentation with smoking occurs mainly during adolescence [6], commonly lead- ing to dependence and chronic disease [6-10]. Although smoking among adults has declined substantially over the past 20 years, the rate of smoking initiation among early adolescents has changed little, actually increasing among girls [6]. Currently, about 64% of high school seniors report having ever smoked and 34% report smoking in the past 30 days [11]. Therefore, preventing smoking among adolescents is an important national health objective [3,5].
Social learning, problem behavior, and social attach- ment models of learning and behavior contribute to our understanding about why adolescents start smoking [12]. According to social learning theory, behavior de- pends greatly on actual and anticipated consequences [13]. Accordingly, youth are more likely to smoke if they anticipate that smoking will result in generally positive outcomes (outcome expectations); this anticipation is developed primarily through personal experience and vicarious observation of others [13]. Consequently, choosing not to smoke may be difficult for youth who perceive that smoking is popular and socially desirable, particularly if they lack confidence in their social abili- ties [13-15].
According to problem behavior theory [16], experi- mentation with smoking can be thought of as part of a constellation of adolescent problem behaviors largely influenced by social-environmental variables. Smok- ing is legal only for adults, although youth can obtain

Psychosocial, School, and Parent Factors Associated with Recent Smoking among Early-Adolescent Boys and Girls1
Bruce Simons-Morton, Ed.D., M.P.H.,*2 Aria Davis Crump, Sc.D.,t Denise L. Haynie, Ph.D., M.P.H.,* Keith E. Saylor, Ph.D.,+ Patricia Eitel, Ph.D.," and Kai Yu, Ph.D .*

*Division of Epidemiology, Statistics, and Prevention Research, National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892; tDepartment of Health Education, University of Maryland at College Park, College Park, Maryland 20742; and $Behavior and Health Research, Inc., Rockville, Maryland
Background. Experimentation with smoking often begins during adolescence, but an adequate under- standing of the factors associated with early initiation remains elusive.
Methods. Sixth- to eighth-grade students (n = 4,263, 67.1% white, 23.5% black, 7.2% other) from seven middle schools were surveyed.

Results. The overall prevalence of recent smoking (past 30 days) of 10.4% was similar for boys and girls and by race, but increased from 3.7% in sixth to 17.8% in eighth grade. These find- ings suggest that the effectiveness of preventive inter- ventions might be improved by targeting parent, school, and student outcomes, including outcome ex- pectations, deviance acceptance, and social norms for both boys and girls, peer influences among boys, and self-control among girls. 01119 American Health Foundation and Academic Press

Smoking is one of the most important, preventable causes of disease [1-5]. Experimentation with smoking occurs mainly during adolescence [6], commonly lead- ing to dependence and chronic disease [6-10]. Although smoking among adults has declined substantially over the past 20 years, the rate of smoking initiation among early adolescents has changed little, actually increasing among girls [6]. Currently, about 64% of high school seniors report having ever smoked and 34% report smoking in the past 30 days [11]. Therefore, preventing smoking among adolescents is an important national health objective [3,5].

Social learning, problem behavior, and social attach- ment models of learning and behavior contribute to our understanding about why adolescents start smoking [12]. According to social learning theory, behavior de- pends greatly on actual and anticipated consequences [13]. Accordingly, youth are more likely to smoke if they anticipate that smoking will result in generally positive outcomes (outcome expectations); this anticipation is developed primarily through personal experience and vicarious observation of others [13]. Consequently, choosing not to smoke may be difficult for youth who perceive that smoking is popular and socially desirable, particularly if they lack confidence in their social abili- ties [13-15].
